The headlines tell us that the world is now more urban than rural. Surely this fact ought to have {{BLANK}}consequences that call for new attitudes and public policies. However, as is often the case with profound change, what actually is happening ' and how we should view these changes ' is extremely murky. From one point of view, the {{BLANK}}migration of people from the countryside to the city is simply the latest chapter in a stray that has played {{BLANK}}worldwide over the last several centimes. First in the most {{BLANK}}nations of the West, and now in the developing world, as more efficient agriculture has reduced the number of people needed in the fields, the rise of new urban economies has drawn them to cities. Every time this push-pull phenomenon has shifted into high {{BLANK}}, whether in London in the Nineteenth century or in Mumbai today, there have been wrenching dislocations followed by attempts on the part of public authorities to stop or slow the Process. These efforts have rarely been {{BLANK}} in the long run, and have often backfired because they have tried to control {{BLANK}}rather than plan for it. In the long run, however, the policies were probably less important than the eventual result ' an equally massive move from the cities back into the countryside. In virtually every affluent nation on earth, the old Nineteenth-century industrial cities have {{BLANK}}outward, allowing densities to plummet at the core as residents move further and further out into {{BLANK}}suburbia and a very low-density exurban penumbra around that. The city of Paris today has a third fewer {{BLANK}} than it did a century ago, and the suburban and exurban territory around it leapfrogs more or less from the English Channel to Burgundy. In this process, the very {{BLANK}}between urban and rural has all but {{BLANK}}as citizens in almost every part of affluent societies are able to participate in what is essentially an urban culture.

Most observers tend to extrapolate current {{BLANK}}and assume that what we see now will continue moving in the same direction ' ever-larger cities, etc. I don t see it that way. I think we'll eventually see a reversal of the 200-year-long cycle of people {{BLANK}}from farms and small towns to big cities. This process of contraction is likely to be problematic and{{BLANK}}. In America, there is certainly the potential for ethnic conflict. Categorically, our colossal metroplexes problematic and will not be {{BLANK}} in a post-oil future ' and despite the wishes and yearnings of many people, the truth is that no combination of alternative {{BLANK}}will permit us to continue living at this scale. Some of our cities will not make it. Phoenix, Tucson, and other Sunbelt cities will dry up and blow {{BLANK}}. In Las Vegas, the excitement will be over. Other mega-cities will have to downscale or face extreme dysfunction. One thing that almost nobody is paying attention to: the skyscraper will not be a viable building type in our {{BLANK}}future. Connecticut has 2,500 parolees, but a {{BLANK}}55,000 people on probation. Probation officers handle an average of 107 cases each 'far too many. We hope to have something meaningful to say in our next book about the efficacy of advertising. This is a huge question that {{BLANK}}everything from commerce to politics to journalism. One of the commercials was an anti-smoking ad ' placed, I believe, by the City of New York. It was a gritty, documentary-style spot, {{BLANK}}a surgeon talking to the camera, then showing the patient he was about to operate on. She is definitely more {{BLANK}}of seeing that foot again than she is of seeing the Wicked Witch of the West again. We talked about it for quite a while; I explained that {{BLANK}}is bad for you, even though in the old days people actually thought smoking was good for you, and now the {{BLANK}}they're sending is that nobody should smoke. K.,' he told the police, according to the reports. Japanese television showed the police holding Mr. Kato on the ground after the {{BLANK}}. The police said the attack began around 12: 30 p.m., when Mr. Kato drove a white, two-ton rental truck into the street in a zigzag pattern, hitting several people.
